column2: AN ADJUSTMENT OF NATURE
column3: AN ADJUSTMENT OF NATURE

column2: In an art exhibition the other day I saw a painting that had been sold for $5,000.
column3: In an art exhibition the other day I saw a painting that had been sold for five thousand dollars.

column2: The painter was a young scrub out of the West named Kraft, who had a favourite food and a pet theory.
column3: The painter was a young scrub out of the West named Kraft, who had a favourite food and a pet theory.

column2: His pabulum was an unquenchable belief in the Unerring Artistic Adjustment of Nature.
column3: His pabulum was an unquenchable belief in the Unerring Artistic Adjustment of Nature.

column2: His theory was fixed around corned-beef hash with poached egg.
column3: His theory was fixed around corned beef hash with poached egg.

column2: There was a story behind the picture, so I went home and let it drip out of a fountain-pen.
column3: There was a story behind the picture, so I went home and let it drip out of a fountain pen.

column2: The idea of Kraft--but that is not the beginning of the story.
column3: The idea of Kraft-but that is not the beginning of the story.

column2: Three years ago Kraft, Bill Judkins (a poet), and I took our meals at Cypher's, on Eighth Avenue.
column3: Three years ago Kraft, Bill Judkins (a poet), and I took our meals at Cypher's, on Eighth Avenue.

column2: I say "took." When we had money, Cypher got it "off of" us, as he expressed it.
column3: I say "took." When we had money, Cypher got it "off of" us, as he expressed it.

column2: We had no credit; we went in, called for food and ate it.
column3: We had no credit; we went in, called for food and ate it.

column2: We paid or we did not pay.
column3: We paid or we did not pay.

column2: We had confidence in Cypher's sullenness and smouldering ferocity.
column3: We had confidence in Cypher's sullenness and smouldering ferocity.

column2: Deep down in his sunless soul he was either a prince, a fool or an artist.
column3: Deep down in his sunless soul he was either a prince, a fool or an artist.

column2: He sat at a worm-eaten desk, covered with files of waiters' checks so old that I was sure the bottomest one was for clams that Hendrik Hudson had eaten and paid for. Cypher had the power, in common with Napoleon III. and the goggle-eyed perch, of throwing a film over his eyes, rendering opaque the windows of his soul.
column3: He sat at a worm eaten desk, covered with files of waiters' checks so old that I was sure the bottomest one was for clams that Hendrik Hudson had eaten and paid for. Cypher had the power, in common with Napoleon the third. and the goggle eyed perch, of throwing a film over his eyes, rendering opaque the windows of his soul.

column2: Once when we left him unpaid, with egregious excuses, I looked back and saw him shaking with inaudible laughter behind his film.
column3: Once when we left him unpaid, with egregious excuses, I looked back and saw him shaking with inaudible laughter behind his film.

column2: Now and then we paid up back scores.
column3: Now and then we paid up back scores.

column2: But the chief thing at Cypher's was Milly.
column3: But the chief thing at Cypher's was Milly.

column2: Milly was a waitress.
column3: Milly was a waitress.

column2: She was a grand example of Kraft's theory of the artistic adjustment of nature.
column3: She was a grand example of Kraft's theory of the artistic adjustment of nature.

column2: She belonged, largely, to waiting, as Minerva did to the art of scrapping, or Venus to the science of serious flirtation.
column3: She belonged, largely, to waiting, as Minerva did to the art of scrapping, or Venus to the science of serious flirtation.

column2: Pedestalled and in bronze she might have stood with the noblest of her heroic sisters as "Liver-and-Bacon Enlivening the World." She belonged to Cypher's.
column3: Pedestalled and in bronze she might have stood with the noblest of her heroic sisters as "Liver and Bacon Enlivening the World." She belonged to Cypher's.

column2: You expected to see her colossal figure loom through that reeking blue cloud of smoke from frying fat just as you expect the Palisades to appear through a drifting Hudson River fog.
column3: You expected to see her colossal figure loom through that reeking blue cloud of smoke from frying fat just as you expect the Palisades to appear through a drifting Hudson River fog.

column2: There amid the steam of vegetables and the vapours of acres of "ham and," the crash of crockery, the clatter of steel, the screaming of "short orders," the cries of the hungering and all the horrid tumult of feeding man, surrounded by swarms of the buzzing winged beasts bequeathed us by Pharaoh, Milly steered her magnificent way like some great liner cleaving among the canoes of howling savages.
column3: There amid the steam of vegetables and the vapours of acres of "ham and," the crash of crockery, the clatter of steel, the screaming of "short orders," the cries of the hungering and all the horrid tumult of feeding man, surrounded by swarms of the buzzing winged beasts bequeathed us by Pharaoh, Milly steered her magnificent way like some great liner cleaving among the canoes of howling savages.

column2: Our Goddess of Grub was built on lines so majestic that they could be followed only with awe.
column3: Our Goddess of Grub was built on lines so majestic that they could be followed only with awe.

column2: Her sleeves were always rolled above her elbows. She could have taken us three musketeers in her two hands and dropped us out of the window.
column3: Her sleeves were always rolled above her elbows. She could have taken us three musketeers in her two hands and dropped us out of the window.

column2: She had seen fewer years than any of us, but she was of such superb Evehood and simplicity that she mothered us from the beginning.
column3: She had seen fewer years than any of us, but she was of such superb Evehood and simplicity that she mothered us from the beginning.

column2: Cypher's store of eatables she poured out upon us with royal indifference to price and quantity, as from a cornucopia that knew no exhaustion.
column3: Cypher's store of eatables she poured out upon us with royal indifference to price and quantity, as from a cornucopia that knew no exhaustion.

column2: Her voice rang like a great silver bell; her smile was many-toothed and frequent; she seemed like a yellow sunrise on mountain tops.
column3: Her voice rang like a great silver bell; her smile was many toothed and frequent; she seemed like a yellow sunrise on mountain tops.

column2: I never saw her but I thought of the Yosemite.
column3: I never saw her but I thought of the Yosemite.

column2: And yet, somehow, I could never think of her as existing outside of Cypher's.
column3: And yet, somehow, I could never think of her as existing outside of Cypher's.

column2: There nature had placed her, and she had taken root and grown mightily.
column3: There nature had placed her, and she had taken root and grown mightily.

column2: She seemed happy, and took her few poor dollars on Saturday nights with the flushed pleasure of a child that receives an unexpected donation.
column3: She seemed happy, and took her few poor dollars on Saturday nights with the flushed pleasure of a child that receives an unexpected donation.

column2: It was Kraft who first voiced the fear that each of us must have held latently.
column3: It was Kraft who first voiced the fear that each of us must have held latently.

column2: It came up apropos, of course, of certain questions of art at which we were hammering.
column3: It came up apropos, of course, of certain questions of art at which we were hammering.

column2: One of us compared the harmony existing between a Haydn symphony and pistache ice cream to the exquisite congruity between Milly and Cypher's.
column3: One of us compared the harmony existing between a Haydn symphony and pistache ice cream to the exquisite congruity between Milly and Cypher's.

column2: There is a certain fate hanging over Milly, said Kraft, "and if it overtakes her she is lost to Cypher's and to us."
column3: There is a certain fate hanging over Milly, said Kraft, "and if it overtakes her she is lost to Cypher's and to us."

column2: She will grow fat? asked Judkins, fearsomely.
column3: She will grow fat? asked Judkins, fearsomely.

column2: She will go to night school and become refined? I ventured anxiously.
column3: She will go to night school and become refined? I ventured anxiously.

column2: It is this, said Kraft, punctuating in a puddle of spilled coffee with a stiff forefinger.
column3: It is this, said Kraft, punctuating in a puddle of spilled coffee with a stiff forefinger.

column2: Speak, I interrupted, much perturbed.

column2: You do not think that Milly will begin to lace?
column3: You do not think that Milly will begin to lace?

column2: One day, concluded Kraft, solemnly, "there will come to Cypher's for a plate of beans a millionaire lumberman from Wisconsin, and he will marry Milly."
column3: One day, concluded Kraft, solemnly, "there will come to Cypher's for a plate of beans a millionaire lumberman from Wisconsin, and he will marry Milly."

column3: Never! exclaimed Judkins and I, in horror.

column3: A lumberman, repeated Kraft, hoarsely.

column2: And a millionaire lumberman! I sighed, despairingly.
column3: And a millionaire lumberman! I sighed, despairingly.

column2: From Wisconsin! groaned Judkins.
column3: From Wisconsin! groaned Judkins.

column2: We agreed that the awful fate seemed to menace her.
column3: We agreed that the awful fate seemed to menace her.

column2: Few things were less improbable.
column3: Few things were less improbable.

column2: Milly, like some vast virgin stretch of pine woods, was made to catch the lumberman's eye.
column3: Milly, like some vast virgin stretch of pine woods, was made to catch the lumberman's eye.

column2: And well we knew the habits of the Badgers, once fortune smiled upon them.
column3: And well we knew the habits of the Badgers, once fortune smiled upon them.

column2: For a while we felt that Milly was on the verge of being lost to us.

column3: It was our love of the Unerring Artistic Adjustment of Nature that inspired us.

column2: We were at our supper of beef stew and dried apples when he trotted in as if on the heels of a dog team, and made one of the mess at our table. With the freedom of the camps he assaulted our ears and claimed the fellowship of men lost in the wilds of a hash house.

column2: We embraced him as a specimen, and in three minutes we had all but died for one another as friends.

column2: He was rugged and bearded and wind-dried.

column2: He had just come off the "trail," he said, at one of the North River ferries.
column3: He had just come off the "trail," he said, at one of the North River ferries.

column3: And now I want some beef stew and canned peaches.

column2: I don't suppose it will knock any of you people off your perch to read a contribution from an animal.

column2: Mr. Kipling and a good many others have demonstrated the fact that animals can express themselves in remunerative English, and no magazine goes to press nowadays without an animal story in it, except the old-style monthlies that are still running pictures of Bryan and the Mont Pelee horror.
